00012 #if !defined(RANDOMLIB_EXACTEXPONENTIAL_HPP)

00014   "$Id: 1850768a6919546b2afa1cd5e017da0704fe612f $"
00015 
00016 #include <RandomLib/RandomNumber.hpp>
00017 
00018 namespace RandomLib {
00019   /**
00020    * \brief Sample exactly from an exponential distribution.
00021    *
00022    * Sample \e x >= 0 from exp(-\e x).  See:
00023    * - J. von Neumann, Various Techniques used in Connection with Random
00024    *   Digits, J. Res. Nat. Bur. Stand., Appl. Math. Ser. 12, 36-38 (1951),
00025    *   reprinted in Collected Works, Vol. 5, 768-770 (Pergammon, 1963).
00026    * - M. Abramowitz and I. A. Stegun, Handbook of Mathematical Functions
00027    *   (National Bureau of Standards, 1964), Sec. 26.8.6.c.2.
00028    * - G. E. Forsythe, Von Neumann's Comparison Method for Random Sampling from
00029    *   Normal and Other Distributions, Math. Comp. 26, 817-826 (1972).
00030    * - D. E. Knuth, TAOCP, Vol 2, Sec 3.4.1.C.3.
00031    * - D. E. Knuth and A. C. Yao, The Complexity of Nonuniform Random Number
00032    *   Generation, in "Algorithms and Complexity" (Academic Press, 1976),
00033    *   pp. 357-428.
00034    * - P. Flajolet and N. Saheb, The Complexity of Generating an
00035    *   Exponentially Distributed Variate, J. Algorithms 7, 463-488 (1986).
00036    *
00037    * The following code illustrates the basic method given by von Neumann:
00038    * \code
00039 // Return a random number x >= 0 distributed with probability exp(-x).
00040 double ExpDist(RandomLib::Random& r) {
00041   for (unsigned k = 0; ; ++k) {
00042     double x = r.Fixed(),       // executed 1/(1-exp(-1)) times on average
00043       p = x, q;
00044     do {
00045       q = r.Fixed();            // executed exp(x)*cosh(x) times on average
00046       if (!(q < p)) return k + x;
00047       p = r.Fixed();            // executed exp(x)*sinh(x) times on average
00048     } while (p < q);
00049   }
00050 }
00051 \endcode
00052    * This returns a result consuming exp(1)/(1 - exp(-1)) = 4.30 random
00053    * numbers on average.  (Von Neumann incorrectly states that the method takes
00054    * (1 + exp(1))/(1 - exp(-1)) = 5.88 random numbers on average.)  Because of
00055    * the finite precision of Random::Fixed(), the code snippet above only
00056    * approximates exp(-\e x).  Instead, it returns \e x with probability \e
00057    * h(1 - \e h)<sup><i>x</i>/<i>h</i></sup> for \e x = \e ih, \e h =
00058    * 2<sup>-53</sup>, and integer \e i >= 0.
00059    *
00060    * The above is precisely von Neumann's method.  Abramowitz and Stegun
00061    * consider a variant: sample uniform variants until the first is less
00062    * than the sum of the rest.  Forsythe converts the < ranking for the runs to
00063    * <= which makes the analysis of the discrete case more difficult.  He also
00064    * drops the "trick" by which the integer part of the deviate is given by the
00065    * number of rejections when finding the fractional part.
00066    *
00067    * Von Neumann says of his method: "The machine has in effect computed a
00068    * logarithm by performing only discriminations on the relative magnitude of
00069    * numbers in (0,1).  It is a sad fact of life, however, that under the
00070    * particular conditions of the Eniac it was slightly quicker to use a
00071    * truncated power series for log(1-\e T) than to carry out all the
00072    * discriminations."
00073    *
00074    * Here the method is extended to use infinite precision uniform deviates
00075    * implemented by RandomNumber and returning \e exact results for the
00076    * exponential distribution.  This is possible because only comparisons are
00077    * done in the method.  The template parameter \e bits specifies the number
00078    * of bits in the base used for RandomNumber (i.e., base =
00079    * 2<sup><i>bits</i></sup>).
00080    *
00081    * For example the following samples from an exponential distribution and
00082    * prints various representations of the result.
00083    * \code
00084 #include <RandomLib/RandomNumber.hpp>
00085 #include <RandomLib/ExactExponential.hpp>
00086 
00087   RandomLib::Random r;
00088   const int bits = 1;
00089   RandomLib::ExactExponential<bits> edist;
00090   for (size_t i = 0; i < 10; ++i) {
00091     RandomLib::RandomNumber<bits> x = edist(r); // Sample
00092     std::pair<double, double> z = x.Range();
00093     std::cout << x << " = "     // Print in binary with ellipsis
00094               << "(" << z.first << "," << z.second << ")"; // Print range
00095     double v = x.Value<double>(r); // Round exactly to nearest double
00096     std::cout << " = " << v << "\n";
00097   }
00098 \endcode
00099    * Here's a possible result:
00100 \verbatim
00101    0.0111... = (0.4375,0.5) = 0.474126
00102    10.000... = (2,2.125) = 2.05196
00103    1.00... = (1,1.25) = 1.05766
00104    0.010... = (0.25,0.375) = 0.318289
00105    10.1... = (2.5,3) = 2.8732
00106    0.0... = (0,0.5) = 0.30753
00107    0.101... = (0.625,0.75) = 0.697654
00108    0.00... = (0,0.25) = 0.0969214
00109    0.0... = (0,0.5) = 0.194053
00110    0.11... = (0.75,1) = 0.867946
00111 \endverbatim
00112    * First number is in binary with ... indicating an infinite sequence of
00113    * random bits.  Second number gives the corresponding interval.  Third
00114    * number is the result of filling in the missing bits and rounding exactly
00115    * to the nearest representable double.
00116    *
00117    * This class uses some mutable RandomNumber objects.  So a single
00118    * ExactExponential object cannot safely be used by multiple threads.  In a
00119    * multi-processing environment, each thread should use a thread-specific
00120    * ExactExponential object.  In addition, these should be invoked with
00121    * thread-specific random generator objects.
00122    *
00123    * @tparam bits the number of bits in each digit.
00124    **********************************************************************/
00125   template<int bits = 1> class ExactExponential {
00126   public:
00127     /**
00128      * Return a random deviate with an exponential distribution, exp(-\e x) for
00129      * \e x >= 0.  Requires 9.316 bits per invocation for \e bits = 1, 6.03
00130      * digits for \e bits = 2, 5.06 digits for \e bits = 3, and 4.30 =
00131      * exp(1)/(1 - exp(-1)) digits for large \e bits.  The frequency of bits in
00132      * the fractional part of the returned result with \e bits = 1:\n
00133 \verbatim
00134      bits freq(%)
00135       1   47.98
00136       2   25.50
00137       3   13.13
00138       4    6.66
00139       5    3.36
00140       6    1.68
00141       7    0.84
00142       8    0.42
00143       9    0.21
00144      10    0.11
00145      11    0.05
00146      12    0.03
00147      13+   0.03
00148 \endverbatim
00149      * The average number of bits in the fraction = 2.054.  The frequency table
00150      * of \e bits > 1 can be generated from the table above.  E.g., with \e
00151      * bits = 2, the result consists of three digits with frequency 3.36% +
00152      * 1.68% = 5.04%.  The relative frequency of the results for the fractional
00153      * part with \e bits = 1 is shown by the histogram\n
00154      * <img src="exphist.png" width=580 height=750
00155      *      alt="exact binary sampling of exponential distribution">\n
00156      * The base of each rectangle gives the range represented by the
00157      * corresponding binary number and the area is proportional to its
00158      * frequency.  A PDF version of this figure is given
00159      * <a href="exphist.pdf">here</a>.  This allows the figure to be magnified
00160      * to show the rectangles for all binary numbers up to 9 bits.
00161      *
00162      * Another way of assessing the efficiency of the algorithm is thru the
00163      * mean value of the balance = (number of random bits consumed) - (number
00164      * of bits in the result).  If we code the result in mixed unary-binary
00165      * notation (integer is given in unary, followed by "0" as a separator,
00166      * followed by the fraction in binary), then the mean balance is 5.680.
00167      *
00168      * @tparam Random the type of the random generator.
00169      * @param[in,out] r a random generator.
00170      * @return the random sample.
00171      **********************************************************************/
00172     template<class Random> RandomNumber<bits> operator()(Random& r) const;
00173   private:
00174     /**
00175      * Return true with probability exp(-\e p) for \e p in (0,1).  For p =
00176      * (0,1), uses 5.89 random bits per invocation for \e bits = 1, 3.81 digits
00177      * for \e bits = 2, 3.20 digits for \e bits = 3, and 2.72 = exp(1) digits
00178      * for \e bits large.  (5.89 is in [5.888, 5.889].  This is close to but
00179      * not equal to (1 + exp(1))/(1 - exp(-1)) = 5.882.)
00180      **********************************************************************/
00181     template<class Random> bool
00182     ExpFraction(Random& r, RandomNumber<bits>& p) const;
00183     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _x;
00184     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _v;
00185     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _w;
00186   };
00187 
00188   template<int bits> template<class Random> RandomNumber<bits>
00189   ExactExponential<bits>::operator()(Random& r) const {
00190     // A simple rejection method gives the fraction part.  The number of
00191     // rejections gives the integer part.
00192     _x.Init();
00193     int k = 0;
00194     while (!ExpFraction(r, _x)) { // Executed 1/(1 - exp(-1)) on average
00195       ++k;
00196       _x.Init();
00197     }
00198     _x.SetInteger(k);
00199     return _x;
00200   }
00201 
00202   template<int bits> template<class Random> bool
00203   ExactExponential<bits>::ExpFraction(Random& r, RandomNumber<bits>& p)
00204     const {
00205     // Implement the von Neumann algorithm.
00206     _w.Init();
00207     if (!_w.LessThan(r, p))     // if (w < p)
00208       return true;
00209     while (true) {              // Unroll loop to avoid copying RandomNumber
00210       _v.Init();                // v = r.Fixed();
00211       if (!_v.LessThan(r, _w))  // if (v < w)
00212         return false;
00213       _w.Init();                // w = r.Fixed();
00214       if (!_w.LessThan(r, _v))  // if (w < v)
00215         return true;
00216     }
00217   }
00218 } // namespace RandomLib
00219 
00220 #endif  // RANDOMLIB_EXACTEXPONENTIAL_HPP
